page.title: Timeline of the feminist art movement in New Zealand

revision.text:
This is a timeline of the [[feminist art movement]] in [[New Zealand]] (or Aotearoa/New Zealand as it is often known in inclusive circles). It lists important figures, collectives, publications, exhibitions and moments that have contributed to discussion and development of the movement. For the indigenous [[Māori people|Māori]] population, the emergence of the [[feminist art movement]] broadly coincided with the emergence of [[Māori Renaissance]].
==1970s==
'''1972'''
The feminist publication [[Broadsheet (magazine)|''Broadsheet'']] is co-founded by Anne Else and [[Sandra Coney]] in [[Auckland]]. It is New Zealand's first feminist magazine, and provides regular arts coverage. It ceases publication in 1997.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Else|first1=Anne|title=Gender inequalities - Areas of discrimination|url=http://www.teara.govt.nz/en/photograph/28622/broadsheet|website=Te Ara - The Online Encyclopedia of New Zealand|accessdate=21 February 2016|date=15 November 2012}}</ref>
'''1974'''
Feminist poet [[Heather McPherson]] starts The Women Artists Group in Christchurch and begins working towards establishing the women's art journal ''Spiral,'' and the Spiral Collective.<ref name=":0">{{Cite web|url=https://medium.com/spiral-collectives/in-the-beginning-there-was-heather-d2ebbf4dd63c|title=In the beginning there was Heather.|last=Evans|first=Marian|date=31 May 2016|website=Spiral Collective|access-date=}}</ref>
'''1975'''
The [[Robert McDougall Art Gallery]] in Christchurch (now the [[Christchurch Art Gallery]]) organises ''Women's Art: An Exhibition of Six Women Artists'' to mark International Women's Year. The exhibition is curated by artist [[Allie Eagle]], then Exhibitions Officer at the gallery.<ref>{{cite book|title=Women's Art: An Exhibition of Six Women Artists|date=1975|publisher=Robert McDougall Art Gallery|location=Christchurch|url=http://christchurchartgallery.org.nz/media/uploads/2010_08/WomansArt1975.pdf|accessdate=21 February 2016}}</ref>
Works from photographer [[Fiona Clark (photographer)|Fiona Clark]]'s series 'Dance Party', taken at a gay lib dance party at Auckland University in 1974, are withdrawn from the touring photography exhibition ''[[The Active Eye]]'' after accusations of indecency.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Wells|first1=Peter|title=Incandescent Moment: Fiona Clark's Go Girl|journal=Art New Zealand|date=Autumn 2003|issue=106|url=http://www.art-newzealand.com/Issue106/Clark.htm}}</ref>
'''1976'''
The women's art journal ''Spiral'' begins publication.<ref name="Cook">{{cite web|last1=Cook|first1=Megan|title=Women’s movement - Arts and spirituality|url=http://www.teara.govt.nz/en/womens-movement/page-9|website=Te Ara - The Online Encyclopedia of New Zealand|accessdate=21 February 2016|date=13 July 2012}}</ref> The ''International Women's Film Festival'' tours Dunedin, Christchurch, Wellington and Auckland.
'''1977'''
Members of Women's artists groups, including [[Heather McPherson]] and [[Allie Eagle]], work together to produce the Women's Art Environment at the Canterbury Society of Arts.<ref name=":0" /><ref>{{Cite journal|last=|first=|date=1977|title=The exhibitions : United Women's Convention 3–8 June|url=http://christchurchartgallery.org.nz/media/uploads/2010_08/1977-05-73.pdf|journal=CSA News|doi=|pmid=|access-date=17 March 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last1=Else|first1=Anne|title=Gender inequalities - Arts and culture|url=http://www.TeAra.govt.nz/en/photograph/28656/womens-art-environment-1977|website=Te Ara: The Online Encyclopedia of New Zealand|accessdate=22 February 2016}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal|last=McPherson|first=Heather|last2=Eagle|first2=Allie|last3=Keir|first3=Anna|last4=Paul|first4=Joanna|last5=Johnson|first5=Rosemary|year=1978|title=The Women's Environment at the '77 Women's Convention|url=|journal=Spiral (Christchurch, N.Z.)|issue= 3|pages=24–40|doi=|pmid=|access-date=}}</ref>
'''1978'''
[[Allie Eagle]] show the works ''This woman died I care'' (based on a banned photograph of a woman who died after having an illegal abortion) and ''Empathy for a Rape Trial Victim''; the exhibition stokes controversy and the artist receives hate mail.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Zusters|first1=Jane|title=Allie Eagle: Artist|journal=Art New Zealand|date=Summer 1994–1995|issue=73|pages=53–57}}</ref>
'''1979'''
The Wellington Women's Gallery opens.<ref name ='Cook'/> Founded by Marian Evans, Anna Keir and Bridie Lonie the gallery was established as a non-profit, designed to 'support and promote women artists’.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Evans|first1=Marian|title=They Might Have Completely Forgotten Us|url=https://medium.com/spiral-collectives/they-might-have-completely-forgotten-us-26b55cd68e69#.qdmzqosww|website=Spiral Collectives|accessdate=10 April 2016|date=9 February 2016}}</ref>
The National Art Gallery (now the [[Museum of New Zealand Te Papa Tongarewa]]) establishes the Women's Art Archives, designed to collect the 'existing, neglected work by women and keep track of new work'. The archive is expanded to include Australian and Pacific women artists.<ref name ='Cook'/>
==1980s==
'''1980'''
The National Art Gallery stages the exhibition ''Women in Communication,'' curated by exhibitions officer Louise Upton. It includes an open forum to support prints and photographs from New Zealand women artists. Work by [[Robin White (artist)|Robin White]], [[Vivian Lynn]], Kate Coolahan and Gillian Chaplin were shown. The exhibition toured to [[Palmerston North]] and [[Whangarei]] and included video tapes from the Los Angeles Women's Video Centre.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Welsh|first=Robyn|date=1 September 1980|title=A gentle triumph for feminist art...but this faintly discriminatory National Gallery show may never be repeated|url=|journal=New Zealand Woman's Weekly}}</ref>
'''1981'''
The [[Wellington Women's Gallery]] stages the exhibition ''Mothers'', which tours New Zealand throughout 1981-1982.<ref name="Cull">{{cite journal|last1=Cull|first1=Chloe|title=Themes in Māori Women’s Art: How the Body ‘Speaks’ Within the Work of Māori Women Artists of the Seventies and Eighties|journal=Oculus|date=2014|url=http://static1.squarespace.com/static/53bb2870e4b0dfc914b2b65a/t/5494bf88e4b050c0df015455/1419034504754/Oculus2014Web_Cull.pdf|accessdate=21 February 2016}}</ref>
'''1982'''
The [[F1 Sculpture Project]] is staged in a large disused factory building on Tory Street in Wellington. A significant number of female artists make temporary installation pieces and a range of events were staged, including a two-day Women Sculptors Seminar.<ref>{{cite web|title=Factory 1 (F1) Sculpture Project 1982|url=http://thecommunityarchive.org.nz/node/65922/description|website=The Community Archive|accessdate=22 February 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|last1=Strathdee|first1=Barbara|title=Women Artists at the F1 New Zealand Sculpture Project|journal=Art New Zealand|date=Autumn 1983|issue=26}}</ref>
[[Vivian Lynn]] shows her major sculptural work [http://collections.tepapa.govt.nz/object/840813 ''Guarden gates''], now in the collection of the [[Museum of New Zealand Te Papa Tongarewa]].<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Kirker|first1=Anne|title=Vivian Lynn's Garden Gates|journal=Art New Zealand|date=Autumn 1983|issue=26|url=http://www.art-newzealand.com/Issues21to30/lynn.htm|accessdate=22 February 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Vivian Lynn talks about her work Guarden gates, 1982|url=http://blog.tepapa.govt.nz/2010/10/29/vivian-lynn-talks-about-her-work-guarden-gates-1982/|website=Museum of New Zealand Te Papa Tongarewa|accessdate=31 December 2014|date=29 October 2010}}</ref>
The Feminist Art Network group is established in Auckland, advocating for an increased profile for work by women and feminist work.<ref>{{cite web|title=Feminist Art Network Archive|url=http://www.aucklandartgallery.com/explore-art-and-ideas/archives/19595|website=Auckland Art Gallery|accessdate=10 April 2016}}</ref>
'''1983'''
The national art magazine ''Art New Zealand'' dedicates its Autumn issue to female artists and the women's art movement. Art historian [[Cheryll Sotheran]] writes an overview of the current state and reception of women's art in New Zealand, noting that 'most critics in New Zealand avoid or condemn exhibitions of women's art which use gender difference as a political weapon. The women whose art receives favourable reviews (or in many cases any reviews at all) are those whose work fits the modernist mould, are not feminists, are asexual and apolitical.'<ref>{{cite web|last1=Sotheran|first1=Cheryll|title=Replacing Women in Art History|url=http://www.art-newzealand.com/Issues21to30/replacing.htm|website=Art New Zealand|accessdate=21 February 2016|date=Autumn 1983}}</ref>
Haeata, the Māori women’s art collective, is established in Wellington. Members include [[Keri Kaa]], [[Patricia Grace]], [[Robyn Kahukiwa]] and [[Irihapeti Ramsden]]. It supports a number of significant female Māori artists and produces and tours exhibitions.<ref name ='Cull'/>
[[Bronwynne Cornish]] is commissioned by the [[Auckland Art Gallery]] to produce a solo work and creates a multi-part ceramic installation titled ''Dedicated to the Kindness of Mothers''.<ref>{{cite journal | last1=Eastmond | first1=Elizabeth | title=Bronwynne Cornish's 'Dedicated to the kindness of mothers' | journal=Art New Zealand | date=Autumn 1984 | issue=30|url=http://www.art-newzealand.com/Issues21to30/cornish.htm}}</ref> In April, [[Gretchen Albrecht]] selects work for a group exhibition arranged by the Outreach Gallery in Auckland, ''New Works By Women''.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Rosier|first1=Pat|title=New Works By Women, 1983|journal=Broadsheet|date=June 1983|issue=110|pages=42}}</ref>
In June, Juliet Batten facilitates ''The Menstrual Maze'' at Greer's Factory in Auckland.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Nicholson|first1=Bronwen|title=The Menstrual Maze|journal=Broadsheet|date=September 1983|issue=112|pages=46}}</ref> The June issue of feminist magazine ''Broadsheet'' includes a special feature on feminist artists. It includes Batten's article 'What is a feminist artist?'.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Batten|first1=Juliet|title=What is a feminist artist?|journal=Broadsheet|date=June 1983|issue=110}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Broadsheet 110, June 1983: 'Special feature on feminist art'|url=http://best-of-3.blogspot.co.nz/2016/03/broadsheet-110-june-1983-special.html|website=Best of 3|accessdate=22 March 2016}}</ref>
1983 also sees the founding of [[Aotearoa Moananui a Kiwa Weavers]], a government funding stream specific to female-dominated art forms, Māori and Pacific weaving. It is now known as [[Te Roopu Raranga Whatu o Aotearoa]] and Māori-only.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.maoriart.org.nz/weavers-c-52_75.html |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2011-10-19 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120304153600/http://www.maoriart.org.nz/weavers-c-52_75.html |archivedate=2012-03-04 |df= }}</ref>
'''1984'''
[[Robyn Kahukiwa]] exhibits her series of paintings ''Wahine toa: women of Māori myth''; the paintings are also reproduced in a book with text by [[Patricia Grace]].<ref name='Mane-Wheoki'/>
'''1985'''
Artist Juliet Batten leads the 'One Hundred Women' event at [[Te Henga (Bethells Beach)]] as part of the ANZART project.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Barton|first1=Christina|title=Post-object and conceptual art - What is post-object art|url=http://www.teara.govt.nz/en/photograph/43823/one-hundred-women|website=Te Ara - The online encyclopedia of New Zealand|accessdate=5 March 2016}}</ref>
'''1986'''
The journal ''Antic'' is launched. Art historian [[Tina Barton]] describes it as 'one forum for a more analytical explication of feminist theory and its applications in the field of literature, criticism and the visual arts, which could be seen as an alternative to the ''Broadsheet'' or ''Art New Zealand'' models.' It ceases publication in 1990.<ref name ='Barton 1993'>{{cite journal|last1=Barton|first1=Christina|title=Ten Years On: Reviewing the terrain for women in art in New Zealand|journal=Art New Zealand|date=Spring 1993|issue=68|pages=50–52}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Antic 1986 - 1990: full list of contents|url=http://best-of-3.blogspot.co.nz/2016/03/antic-1986-1990-full-list-of-contents.html|website=Best of 3|accessdate=21 March 2016}}</ref>
Art critic Lita Barrie delivers a paper, 'Remissions: toward a deconstruction of phallic unequivocality: deferrals', at the Critic's Conference at the National Art Gallery. Informed by contemporary French theory and calling for a 'critical feminist art practice', Barrie attacked the essentialist form of feminist art practice common at the time, sending 'shock waves through the community of women artists to whom her paper was addressed'.<ref name = 'Barton 1993'/><ref>{{cite web|last1=Rice|first1=Rebecca|last2=Williams|first2=Mark|title=Criticism and the arts - Issues of identity, 1960s onwards|url=http://www.teara.govt.nz/en/criticism-and-the-arts/page-4|website=Te Ara - The Online Encyclopedia of New Zealand|accessdate=21 February 2016}}</ref>
The first edition of Anne Kirker's ''New Zealand women artists'' is published by Reed Methuen.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Kirker|first1=Anne|title=New Zealand women artists|date=1986|publisher=Reed Methuen|location=Auckland|isbn=0474001814}}</ref>
Elizabeth Eastmond and Merimeri Penfold's ''Women and the Arts in New Zealand: Forty Works 1936–1986'' is published by Penguin Books.<ref name ='Eastmond and Penfold>{{cite book|last1=Penfold|first1=Merimeri|last2=Eastmond|first2=Elizabeth|title=Women and the Arts in New Zealand: Forty Works 1936–1986|date=1986|publisher=Auckland|location=Penguin Books|isbn=014009234X}}</ref>
The Haeata collective organises the exhibition ''Karanga Karanga'', which shows in Auckland, Wellington and Gisborne.<ref name ='Cull'/>
[[Vivian Lynn]] shows ''Gates of the Goddess – a southern crossing attended by the Goddess'' at the [[Govett-Brewster Art Gallery]]; the work is now in the collection of the [[Auckland Art Gallery]]).<ref name='Eastmond and Penfold'/><ref>{{cite web|last1=Cook|first1=Megan|title='Women's movement – Arts and spirituality'|url=http://www.TeAra.govt.nz/en/artwork/27927/goddess-gates|website=Te Ara – the Encyclopedia of New Zealand|accessdate=22 February 2016|date=16 October 2012}}</ref><ref>{{Cite book|title = Women and the arts in New Zealand – Forty Works: 1936–86|last = Eastmond|first = Elizabeth|publisher = Penguin Books|year = 1986|isbn = 014009234X|location = Auckland|pages = |last2 = Penfold|first2 = Merimeri}}</ref>
'''1988'''
The National Art Gallery organises an exhibition of the work of American artist [[Barbara Kruger]], curated by [[Jenny Harper]]. The exhibition is held at the Gallery's satellite contemporary art space, Shed 11. Kruger visits New Zealand for the opening of the exhibition and delivers a public lecture.<ref name="Clifford">{{cite web|last1=Clifford|first1=Jess|title=Looking out, looking in|url=http://arts.tepapa.govt.nz/off-the-wall/7693/looking-in-looking-out|website=Off The Wall|publisher=Museum of New Zealand Te Papa Tongarewa|accessdate=21 February 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Untitled (We are unsuitable for framing)|url=http://collections.tepapa.govt.nz/object/36996|website=Museum of New Zealand Te Papa Tongarewa|accessdate=21 February 2016}}</ref>
Marian Evans, Bridie Lonie and Tilly Lloyd co-edit ''A Women's picture book : 25 women artists of Aotearoa New Zealand''.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Evans|first1=Marian|last2=Lonie|first2=Bridie|last3=Lloyd|first3=Tilly|title=A Women's picture book : 25 women artists of Aotearoa New Zealand|date=1988|publisher=GP Books|location=Wellington|isbn=0477013953}}</ref> The authors intend to include a number of Māori artists, including [[Irihapeti Ramsden]], [[Jacqueline Fraser]] and [[Robyn Kahukiwa]] but several withdraw after concerns about material included in the book which they felt to breach [[Tapu (Polynesian culture)|tapu]].<ref name="Mane-Wheoki">{{cite web|last1=Mane-Wheoki|first1=Jonathan|title=Contemporary Māori art – ngā toi hōu - New developments in contemporary art|url=http://www.teara.govt.nz/en/contemporary-maori-art-nga-toi-hou/page-3|website=Te Ara - The Online Encyclopedia of New Zealand|accessdate=21 February 2016|date=14 November 2014}}</ref>
[[Shona Rapira Davies]] and [[Robyn Kahukiwa]] collaborate on the exhibition ''Whakamaemae'' ('To feel pain') at [[City Gallery Wellington]]; the exhibition includes Rapira Davies' major sculptural work ''Nga Morehu''.<ref>{{cite web|title=Nga Morehu|url=http://collections.tepapa.govt.nz/object/43005|website=Museum of New Zealand Te Papa Tongarewa|accessdate=21 February 2016}}</ref>
'''1989'''
Following on from the exhibition of Kruger's work, National Art Gallery director [[Luit Bieringa]] curates an exhibition of work by photographer [[Cindy Sherman]], also staged at Shed 11.<ref name="Clifford"/>
==1990s==
'''1990'''
This year marks New Zealand's sesquicentennial. A number of Māori women artists withdraw from the National Art Gallery's exhibition ''Kohia ko Taikaka Anake'' after learning that senior female artists will be made subordinate to senior male artists in its presentation.<ref name="Mane-Wheoki"/> The Haeata collective presents ''Hineteiwaiwa'', the ‘womanhouse’, for the ''Mana Tiriti'' exhibition at [[City Gallery Wellington]].<ref name="Mane-Wheoki"/>
'''1992'''
[[Cheryll Sotheran]] is appointed as the founding CEO of the new [[Museum of New Zealand Te Papa Tongarewa]], which merges New Zealand's national museum and national art gallery.
'''1993'''
This year marks the 100th anniversary of [[women's suffrage in New Zealand]].
''Art New Zealand'' dedicates its Spring issue that year to female artists and feminist topics. Art historian Tina Barton is commissioned to write a review of the decade since the last issue of the magazine devoted to women artists.<ref name ='Barton 1993'/> A number of exhibitions exploring women in New Zealand's art history and feminist art issues are staged around the country, including ''[[Alter / Image]]'' in Wellington and Auckland, ''Mediatrix : new works by seven women artists'' at Artspace in Auckland (curated by Priscilla Pitts and featuring Mary-Louise Browne, Denise Kum, [[Julia Morison]], Marie Shannon, Deborah Smith, Aromea Tahiwi and [[Barbara Tuck]]); ''Unruly Practices'' (a series of solo projects by feminist artists living in Auckland - [[Carole Shepheard]], [[Claudia Pond Eyley]], Mary McIntyre, [[Christine Hellyar]] and [[Sylvia Siddell]]) at [[Auckland Art Gallery]], ''White Camellias : a century of women's artmaking in Canterbury'' and ''Women on women : art in Dunedin since 1893'' at the [[Dunedin Public Art Gallery]], curated by Linda Tyler.<ref>{{cite web|title=Mediatrix : new work by seven women artists : an exhibition to mark the centenary of women's suffrage in New Zealand|url=http://natlib.govt.nz/records/22161487|website=National Library of New Zealand|accessdate=25 December 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=White Camellias: A Century of Art Making by Canterbury Women|url=http://christchurchartgallery.org.nz/exhibitions/white-camellias|website=Christchurch Art Gallery|accessdate=25 December 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Women on women : art in Dunedin since 1893|url=http://natlib.govt.nz/records/22206191|website=National Library of New Zealand|accessdate=25 December 2015}}</ref> ''Alter / Image'' was also one of four inaugural exhibitions, all featuring female artists, that marked the opening of [[City Gallery Wellington]] in its new location in the old Public Library building in Wellington's Civic Square; the others were ''[[Rosemarie Trockel]]'', ''Te Whare Puanga'' (recent weaving and tivaevae by Maori and Pacific Island women in Wellington) and ''He Tohu: The New Zealand Room'', a site-specific project by [[Jacqueline Fraser]].<ref>{{cite journal|title=Exhibition advertisement|journal=Art New Zealand|date=Spring 1993|issue=68|page=unpaginated}}</ref> An updated version of Anne Kirker's 1986 book ''New Zealand Women Artists'' is published as ''New Zealand women artists : a survey of 150 years'' by Reed Methuen.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Kirker|first1=Anne|title=New Zealand women artists : a survey of 150 years|date=1993|publisher=Auckland|location=Reed Methuen|isbn=9768097302}}</ref>
'''1994'''
Australian art magazine ''Artlink'' devotes its Autumn issue to 'Art & the Feminist Project'. The issue features articles by New Zealand writers [[Tina Barton]] ('Making (a) difference: Suffrage year celebrations and the visual arts in New Zealand') and Anne Kirker ('Re-orienting feminism in Aotearoa').<ref>{{cite web|title=Art & the Feminist Project|url=https://www.artlink.com.au/issues/1410/art-26-the-feminist-project/|website=Artlink|accessdate=26 February 2016}}</ref>
==2000s–present==
'''2000'''
The [[Govett-Brewster Art Gallery]] stages ''In glorious dreams'', an exhibition of new work by women artists.<ref>{{cite web|title=In glorious dreams|url=http://nlnzcat.natlib.govt.nz/vwebv/holdingsInfo?bibId=610512|website=National Library of New Zealand catalogue|accessdate=23 February 2016}}</ref>
'''2001'''
Artist [[Jacqueline Fraser]] is selected, along with Peter Robinson, to represent New Zealand in its first participation at the [[Venice Biennale]].<ref>{{cite web|last1=Mane-Wheoki|first1=Jonathan|title=Contemporary Māori art – ngā toi hōu - Contemporary Māori art in the 2000s|url=http://www.teara.govt.nz/en/contemporary-maori-art-nga-toi-hou/page-5|website=Te Ara - the Encyclopedia of New Zealand|accessdate=2 January 2015}}</ref>
'''2002'''
The Govett-Brewster Art Gallery stages ''Go Girl'', a survey of the work of photographer Fiona Clark. The exhibition includes works withdrawn from the 1975 exhibition ''The Active Eye'' after accusations of indecency relating to their depiction of the LGBT community.<ref>{{cite web|title=Go Girl at New Plymouth’s Govett-Brewster Gallery|url=http://www.scoop.co.nz/stories/CU0209/S00079/go-girl-at-new-plymouths-govett-brewster-gallery.htm|website=Scoop.co.nz|accessdate=23 February 2016|date=25 September 2002}}</ref>
'''2004'''
The Museum of New Zealand Te Papa Tongarewa stages ''Judy Darragh: So ... You Made It'', the only solo exhibition of a contemporary New Zealand artist presented at the museum between its opening in 1998 and the 'Toi Art' refreshment that opened in 2018.<ref>{{cite web|title=Judy Darragh: So ... you made it?|url=http://www.tepapa.govt.nz/WhatsOn/exhibitions/Pages/JudyDarragh.aspx|website=Museum of New Zealand Te Papa Tonagrewa|accessdate=23 February 2016}}</ref>
'''2008'''
The Museum of New Zealand Te Papa Tongarewa presents the exhibition ''We are unsuitable for framing''. Curated by Charlotte Huddleston, the exhibition is titled after a work by Barbara Kruger held in the museum's collection and included in the artist's 1988 exhibition in Wellington. It includes works produced between 1974 and 2005 and aimed to explore 'aspects of identity, gender, sexuality, and mythology'.<ref>{{cite web|title=We are unsuitable for framing|url=http://www.tepapa.govt.nz/WhatsOn/exhibitions/Pages/WeAreUnsuitableForFraming.aspx|website=Museum of New Zealand Te Papa Tongarewa|accessdate=21 February 2016}}</ref>
'''2009'''
The [[Adam Art Gallery]] holds a workshop titled 'Out Loud: Using the ‘F’ Word Today', featuring a range of female curators and artists, to accompany its survey exhibition of the work of [[Vivian Lynn]], '' I, HERE, NOW Vivian Lynn''.<ref>{{cite web|title=February-March 2009|url=http://www.adamartgallery.org.nz/calendar/february-march/|website=Adam Art Gallery|accessdate=22 February 2016}}</ref>
'''2012'''
[[The Dowse Art Museum]] stages the touring exhibition ''In Spite of Ourselves: Approaching Documentary'', which includes a work by Qatari/US artist, Sophia Al-Maria, ''For Your Eyes Only'' (2007) which shows female members of a family preparing for a wedding in a space in a house only used by women and children. The artists requests that the video work only be shown to female visitors: when the museum complies with this request protests are made that men are being excluded from the museum.<ref>{{cite web|title=In Spite of Ourselves: Approaching Documentary|url=http://dowse.org.nz/exhibitions/detail/in-spite-of-ourselves-approaching-documentary|website=The Dowse Art Museum|accessdate=23 February 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=In Spite of Everything|url=http://dowse.org.nz/news/blog/2012/in-spite-of-everything|website=The Dowse Art Museum|accessdate=23 February 2016}}</ref>
'''2013'''
Writer Thomasin Sleigh publishes an analysis of the contemporary editorial approach of ''Art New Zealand'', concluding that 'the artist most likely for Art New Zealand to run an article on would be a Pakeha painter, and his work would most likely be written about by a Pakeha man employed by an academic institution.'<ref>{{cite web|last1=Sleigh|first1=Thomasin|title=The Stuttering Conversation: Art New Zealand in 2013|url=http://lumiere.net.nz/index.php/art-new-zealand-in-2013/|website=The Lumiere Reader|accessdate=22 February 2016|date=21 February 2013}}</ref>
'''2014'''
Art History honours students at the University of Auckland organise ''Voicing the Visible'', an exhibition of female and feminist artists work from the university's collection for the Gus Fisher Gallery.<ref>{{cite web|title=Voicing the Visible|url=http://www.ingenio-magazine.com/voicing-the-visible/|website=Ingenio|publisher=University of Auckland Alumni organisation|accessdate=10 April 2016}}</ref>
'''2015'''
[[Enjoy Public Art Gallery]] in Wellington presents ''Enjoy Feminisms'', an exhibition programme that sought to demonstrate the multiple meanings of feminism to contemporary artists, and publishes ''Love Feminisms'', an online journal to accompany the exhibition programme.<ref>{{cite web|title=Enjoy Feminisms|url=http://www.enjoy.org.nz/node/3665|website=Enjoy Public Art Gallery|accessdate=21 February 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Love Feminisms|url=http://journal.enjoy.org.nz/love-feminisms/editorial|website=Enjoy Public Art Gallery|accessdate=21 February 2016}}</ref>
The [[Adam Art Gallery]] presents ''Fragments of a World: Artists Working in Film and Photography 1973–1987'', curated by Dr Sandy Callister, an exhibition investigating 'the intersection of feminism, new technologies, and a disruptive epoch'.<ref>{{cite web|title=Fragments of a World|url=http://www.adamartgallery.org.nz/past-exhibitions/10053/|website=Adam Art Gallery|accessdate=21 February 2016}}</ref>
[[The Dowse Art Museum]] in Lower Hutt organises an 'Art + Feminism' Wikipedia edit-a-thon to improve coverage of New Zealand women artists.<ref>{{cite web|title=Art + Feminism edit-a-thon|url=http://dowse.org.nz/events/art-feminism-wikipedia-edit-a-thon|website=The Dowse Art Museum|accessdate=21 February 2016}}</ref>
'''2016'''
The Dowse Art Museum organises 'Four Waves of Feminism', a symposium exploring current and historical feminist art, activity and research.<ref>{{cite web|title=Four Waves of Feminism|url=http://dowse.org.nz/events/four-waves-of-feminism|website=The Dowse Art Museum|accessdate=30 April 2016}}</ref>
Barbara Brookes' ''A History of New Zealand Women'' is published by [[Bridget Williams Books]]. Heavily illustrated with the work of women artists including [[Olivia Spencer Bower]], [[Rita Angus]], [[Margaret Stoddart]] and [[Louise Henderson]], the reproductions are presented 'not simply as illustrations for the immediate text but as a narrative in themselves. ... this is, presenting a woman's perspective.'<ref>{{cite book|last1=Brookes|first1=Barbara|title=A history of New Zealand women|date=2016|publisher=Bridget Williams Books|location=Wellington|isbn=9780908321476|page=486}}</ref>
The Adam Art Gallery presents ''Bad Visual Systems'', an exhibition by Berlin-based, New Zealand-born artist Ruth Buchanan. For the exhibition Buchanan shows the work of German artists Judith Hopf and [[Marianne Wex]]. The exhibition presents panels from Wex's photographic book ''Let’s Take Back Our Space''; sheets from the book had been printed in a 1984 edition of the feminist magazine ''Broadsheet'' when Wex was living in Wellington.<ref>{{cite web|title=Bad Visual Systems|url=http://www.adamartgallery.org.nz/current-exhibition/|website=Adam Art Gallery|accessdate=29 October 2016}}</ref>
'''2018'''
2018 marks the 125th anniversary of women's suffrage in New Zealand.
Christchurch Art Gallery presents ''We Do This'', an exhibition of work by women artists. largely from the gallery's permanent collection, in a 'recharged contemporary hang to mark 125 years of women’s suffrage.'<ref>{{cite web |title=We Do This |url=https://christchurchartgallery.org.nz/exhibitions/we-do-this |website=Christchurch Art Gallery Te Puna o Waiwhetū |accessdate=18 June 2018}}</ref>

The '''vaginal epithelium''' is the [[Gland|aglandular]] inner lining of the [[vagina]] consisting of multiple layers of ([[Epithelium|squamous]]) cells.<ref>Up to 26 layers have been seen - see Pathology, American Society for Colposcopy and Cervical; Mayeaux, E. J.; Cox, J. Thomas (2011-12-28). Modern Colposcopy Textbook and Atlas. Lippincott Williams & Wilkins. {{isbn|9781451153835}}.</ref><ref>{{Cite book|url=https://www.worldcat.org/oclc/868922790|title=Immunology of the female genital tract|last=E R|first=Weissenbacher|publisher=|year=|isbn=9783642149054|location=Heidelberg|pages=16|oclc=868922790}}</ref><ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Q8DxCAAAQBAJ&pg=PA15&dq=vaginal+rugae&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjDwJjtiKnZAhVEcq0KHbZxDPQQ6AEIUzAI#v=onepage&q=vaginal%20rugae&f=false|title=Atlas of Human Reproduction: By Scanning Electron Microscopy | vauthors = Hafez ES, Kenemans P |date=2012-12-06|publisher=Springer Science & Business Media|isbn=9789401181402}}</ref> The basal membrane provides the support for the first layer of the epithelium-the basal layer. The intermediate layers lie upon the basal layer and the superficial layer is the outermost layer of the epithelium.<!-- The layers between the basal layer and the most superficial layer are the intermediate layers. The wall of the vagina from the lumen outwards consists firstly of a [[mucous membrane]] of [[stratified squamous epithelium]] with an underlying [[lamina propria]] of [[connective tissue]]. Secondly, there is a layer of [[smooth muscle]] with bundles of circular fibers internal to longitudinal fibers. Lastly is an outer layer of connective tissue called the [[adventitia]]. Some texts list four layers by counting the two sublayers of the mucosa (epithelium and lamina propria) separately.--><ref name="Brown"/><ref name="Arulkumaran"/> Anatomists have described the epithelium as consisting of as many as 40 distinct layers.{{fact|date=November 2018}}<ref name=":8">{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Q8DxCAAAQBAJ&pg=PA15&dq=vaginal+rugae&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjDwJjtiKnZAhVEcq0KHbZxDPQQ6AEIUzAI#v=onepage&q=vaginal%20rugae&f=false|title=Atlas of Human Reproduction: By Scanning Electron Microscopy | vauthors= Hafez ES, Kenemans P | date = 2012-12-06|publisher=Springer Science & Business Media|year=|isbn=9789401181402|location=|pages=1–6}}</ref> The mucous found on the epithelium is secreted by the cervix and uterus.<ref name=":11">{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=XzKzCwAAQBAJ&pg=PA185&lpg=PA185#v=onepage&q&f=false|title=USMLE Step 1 Lecture Notes 2017: Anatomy|last=|first=|date=|publisher=Simon and Schuster|year=2017|isbn=9781506209463|location=|pages=185|language=en}}</ref> The rugae of the epithelium create a involuted surface and result in a large surface area that covers 360 cm<sup>3</sup>.<ref name=":9"/> This large surface area allows the trans-epithelial absorption of some medications via the vaginal route.
In the course of the [[Biological life cycle|reproductive cycle]], the vaginal epithelium is subject to normal, cyclic changes, that are influenced by [[estrogen]]: with increasing circulating levels of the [[hormone]], there is proliferation of epithelial cells along with an increase in the number of cell layers.<ref name="Nauth22">{{cite book | first1 = Hans Friedrich | last1 = Nauth | name-list-format = vanc | title = Gynäkologische Zytodiagnostik|edition= 2nd | publisher =Georg Thieme| location =Stuttgart|year=2014| page = 22 | isbn=978-3-13-131092-7 | language=German }}</ref><ref name="Knörr">{{citation/core|Surname1=Karl Knörr, Henriette Knörr-Gärtner, Fritz K. Beller, Christian Lauritzen|Title=Geburtshilfe und Gynäkologie: Physiologie und Pathologie der Reproduktion| edition = 3rd | publisher = Springer| location =Berlin|year=2013| pages = 24–25 |isbn=978-3-642-95584-6|language=German }}</ref> As cells proliferate and mature, they undergo partial cornification.<ref name=":9">{{cite journal | vauthors = Anderson DJ, Marathe J, Pudney J | title = The structure of the human vaginal stratum corneum and its role in immune defense | journal = American Journal of Reproductive Immunology | volume = 71 | issue = 6 | pages = 618–23 | date = June 2014 | pmid = 24661416 | doi = 10.1111/aji.12230 | url = http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1111/aji.12230/abstract | pmc = 4024347 }}</ref><ref name=":3">{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=3lEtAxpNLewC&pg=SA2-PA29-IA2#v=onepage&q&f=false|title=Modern Colposcopy Textbook and Atlas|last=Pathology|first=American Society for Colposcopy and Cervical|last2=Mayeaux|first2=E. J.|last3=Cox|first3=J. Thomas | name-list-format = vanc |date=2011-12-28|publisher=Lippincott Williams & Wilkins|isbn=9781451153835}}</ref> Although hormone induced changes occur in the other tissues and organs of the female reproductive system, the vaginal epithelium is more sensitive and its structure is an indicator of estrogen levels.<ref name="Knörr" /><ref name=":3" /><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.vivo.colostate.edu/hbooks/pathphys/reprod/vc/index.html|title=Vaginal Cytology: Introduction and Index|website=www.vivo.colostate.edu|language=en|access-date=2018-02-06}}</ref> Some [[Langerhans cell]]s and [[melanocyte]]s are also present in the epithelium.<ref name=":3" /> The epithelium of the [[ectocervix]] is contiguous with that of the vagina, possessing the same properties and function.<ref name=":1" /> The vaginal epithelium is divided into layers of cells, including the [[Stratum basale|basal cells]], the parabasal cells, the superficial [[squamous cell|squamous flat cells]], and the intermediate cells.<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=40yVAwAAQBAJ&pg=PA2#v=onepage&q&f=false|title=DC Dutta's Textbook of Gynecology|last=Dutta|first=D. C.|last2=Konar|first2=Hiralal| name-list-format = vanc |date=2014-04-30|publisher=JP Medical Ltd|isbn=9789351520689}}</ref><ref name="Mayeaux">{{cite book|title=Modern Colposcopy Textbook and Atlas | vauthors = Mayeaux EJ, Cox TJ |publisher=[[Lippincott Williams & Wilkins]]|year=2011|isbn=145115383X|page=|accessdate=December 11, 2017|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=3lEtAxpNLewC&pg=SA2-PA29-IA2&dq=}}</ref><ref name=":11" /> The superficial cells [[Exfoliation corrosion#Exfoliation|exfoliate]] continuously and basal cells replace the superficial cells that die and slough off from the [[stratum corneum]].<ref name="Beckmann">{{cite book |vauthors=Beckmann CR |title=Obstetrics and Gynecology|publisher=[[Lippincott Williams & Wilkins]]|isbn=0781788072|pages=241–245|year=2010 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=0flWgd3OJLEC&pg=PA241}}</ref><ref name="Blaustein2002">{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=tuKGMxGRKa8C|title=Blaustein's Pathology of the Female Genital Tract|publisher=Springer|year=2002 | veditors = Kurman RJ |edition=5th|page=154}}</ref><ref name="Robboy">{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=ab545XL-MBEC&pg=PA112|title=Robboy's Pathology of the Female Reproductive Tract|author=Stanley J. Robboy|first=|publisher=[[Elsevier Health Sciences]]|year=2009|isbn=0443074771|location=|page=111|pages=|accessdate=November 5, 2014}}</ref> Under the stratus corneum is the [[stratum granulosum]] and [[stratum spinosum]].<ref name=":5">{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=vkox3JS83k8C&pg=PA604&lpg=PA604&dq=Stratum+spinosum+vagina&source=bl&ots=zffHY9hhRi&sig=QBtc7aVJxHuIxYTKHyMyJ2OGibk&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwja6_bIzIXYAhWlUd8KHUzHD9I4ChDoAQgmMAA#v=onepage&q=Stratum%20spinosum%20vagina&f=false|title=Fundamentals of Toxicologic Pathology|last=Haschek|first=Wanda M.|last2=Rousseaux|first2=Colin G.|last3=Wallig|first3=Matthew A. | name-list-format = vanc |date=2009-11-23|publisher=Academic Press|isbn=9780080919324}}</ref> The cells of the vaginal epithelium retain an usually high level of glycogen compared to other epithelial tissue in the body.<ref name="Blaustein2002b">{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=tuKGMxGRKa8C|title=Blaustein's Pathology of the Female Genital Tract|publisher=Springer|year=2002 | veditors = Kurman RJ | edition = 5th | page = 154 }}</ref> The surface patterns on the cells themselves are circular and arranged in longitudinal rows.<ref name=":8" /> The epithelial cells of the uterus possess some of the same characteristics of the vaginal epithelium.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Yarbrough|first=Victoria L.|last2=Winkle|first2=Sean|last3=Herbst-Kralovetz|first3=Melissa M.|date=2015-05-01|title=Antimicrobial peptides in the female reproductive tract: a critical component of the mucosal immune barrier with physiological and clinical implications (review)|url=http://academic.oup.com/humupd/article/21/3/353/675538/Antimicrobial-peptides-in-the-female-reproductive|journal=Human Reproduction Update|language=en|volume=21|issue=3|pages=353–377|doi=10.1093/humupd/dmu065|issn=1355-4786|via=}}</ref>
==Structure== Vaginal epithelium forms transverse ridges or [[vaginal rugae|rugae]] that are most prominent in the lower third of the vagina. This structure of the epithelium results in an increased surface area that allows for stretching.<ref name="Snell">{{cite book|vauthors=Snell RS|title=Clinical Anatomy: An Illustrated Review with Questions and Explanations|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=5s7jDVQkCfoC&pg=PA98 |year=2004|publisher=Lippincott Williams & Wilkins|isbn=978-0-7817-4316-7|page=98}}</ref><ref name="Dutta">{{cite book|vauthors=Dutta DC |title=DC Dutta's Textbook of Gynecology |year=2014|publisher=JP Medical Ltd|isbn=9351520684|pages=2–7|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=40yVAwAAQBAJ&pg=PA2}}</ref><ref name=":9"/> This layer of epithelium is protective and its uppermost surface of cornified (dead) cells that are unique in that they are permeable to microorganisms that are part of the vaginal flora. [[lamina propria|The lamina propria]] of [[connective tissue]] is under the epithelium.<ref name="Brown">{{cite book|last=Brown|first=Laurence| name-list-format = vanc |title=Pathology of the Vulva and Vagina|accessdate=February 21, 2014|year=2012|publisher=[[Springer Science+Business Media]]|isbn=0857297570|pages=6–7|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Yv2CMHoVR9wC&pg=PA6}}</ref><ref name="Arulkumaran">{{cite book | first1 = Sabaratnam | last1 = Arulkumaran | first2 = Lesley | last2 = Regan | first3 = Aris| last3 = Papageorghiou | first4 = Ash | last4 = Monga | first5 = David | last5 = Farquharson | name-list-format = vanc | title = Oxford Desk Reference: Obstetrics and Gynaecology|accessdate=February 21, 2014|year=2011|publisher=[[Oxford University Press]]|isbn=0191620874|page=471|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=lRaWcRYx_7YC&pg=PA471}}</ref>
===Cells=== {| class="wikitable" |+ !cell type !Features !Diameter !Nuclei !Notes |- |[[Stratum basale|basal cell]] |round to cylindrical, narrow basophilic cytoplasmic space |12-14 μm |distinct, 8–10 μm in size |only in case of severe epithelial atrophy and in repair processes after inflammation |- | [[stratum granulosum]] |part of the parabasal layer, round to longitudinal oval, cytoplasm basophilic |20 μm |clear cell nucleus |Frequent glycogen storage , thickened cell margins and decentralized cell nucleus; Predominant cell type in menopausal women<ref name=":3" /><ref name="Dutta" /><ref name="Mayeaux" /><ref name=":5" /> |- |[[stratum spinosum]] |part of the parabasal layer | | |<ref name=":5" /><ref name="Mayeaux" /><ref name="Dutta" /> |- |[[Intermediate mesoderm|intermediate cell]] |oval to polygonal, cytoplasm basophilic |30–50 μm |approx. 8 μm, decreasing core-plasma relation with increase in size |in pregnancy : barge-like with thickened cell margin ("navicular cells") |- |superficial [[squamous cell|squamous flat cells]] |polygonal, baso- or [[eosinophilic]], transparent, partially [[keratohyalin]]e granule |50–60 microns |vesicular and slightly stainable or shrunken |<ref name="Dutta" /><ref name="Mayeaux" /> |- |stratum corneum |exfoliate, slough off | |become detached from the epithelium |<ref name="Blaustein2002" /><ref name="Robboy" /><ref name="Beckmann" /> |}
=== Basal cells === The basal layer of the epithelium is the most mitotically active and reproduces new cells.<ref name="Blaustein2002" /> This layer is composed of one layer of cuboidal cells laying on top of the basal membrane.<ref name=":8" />
=== Parabasal cells === The parabasal cells include the stratum granulousum and the stratum spinosum.<ref name=":5" /> In these two layers, cells from the lower basal layer transition from active metabolic activity to death (apoptosis). In these mid-layers of the epithelia, the cells begin to lose their [[mitochondria]] and other cell organelles.<ref name="Blaustein2002" /><ref>{{cite book|title=Reproductive and developmental toxicology|last=Gupta|first=Ramesh| name-list-format = vanc |publisher=Academic Press|year=2011|isbn=978-0-12-382032-7|location=London|pages=1005}}</ref> The multiple layers of parabasal cells are polyhedral in shape with prominent nuclei.<ref name=":8" />
=== Intermediate cells === Intermediate cells make abundant glycogen and store it.<ref name="Wehrend17" /><ref name=":6" /> [[Estrogen]] induces the intermediate and superficial cells to fill with [[glycogen]].<ref name="Robboy" /><ref name=":7">{{cite journal | vauthors = Nunn KL, Forney LJ | title = Unraveling the Dynamics of the Human Vaginal Microbiome | journal = The Yale Journal of Biology and Medicine | volume = 89 | issue = 3 | pages = 331–337 | date = September 2016 | pmid = 27698617 | pmc = 5045142 }}</ref> The intermediate cells contain nuclei and are larger than the parabasal cells and more flattened. Some have identified a transitional layer of cells above intermediate layer<ref name=":8" />
=== Superficial cells === [[Estrogen]] induces the intermediate and superficial cells to fill with [[glycogen]].<ref name="Robboy" /><ref name=":7" /> Several layers of superficial cells exist that consist large, flattened cells with indistinct nuclei. The superficial cells are exfoliated continuously.<ref name=":8" />
=== Cell junctions === The junctions between epithelial cells regulate the passage of molecules, bacteria and viruses by functioning as a physical barrier.<ref name=":1" /><ref name=":9"/> The three types of structural adhesions between epithelial cells are: tight junctions, [[adherens junction]]s, and [[desmosome]]s. "Tight junctions ([[Tight junction|zonula occludens]]) are composed of [[transmembrane protein]]s that make contact across the intercellular space and create a seal to restrict [[transmembrane proteins]] difusion.<ref name="Beckmann" /> of molecules across the epithelial sheet. Tight junctions also have an organizing role in epithelial polarization by limiting the mobility of membrane-bound molecules between the apical and basolateral domains of the plasma membrane of each epithelial cell. Adherens junctions (zonula adherens) connect bundles of [[Microfilament|actin filaments]] from cell to cell to form a continuous adhesion belt, usually just below the microfilaments."<ref name=":1">{{cite journal | vauthors = Blaskewicz CD, Pudney J, Anderson DJ | title = Structure and function of intercellular junctions in human cervical and vaginal mucosal epithelia | journal = Biology of Reproduction | volume = 85 | issue = 1 | pages = 97–104 | date = July 2011 | pmid = 21471299 | doi = 10.1095/biolreprod.110.090423 | url = https://academic.oup.com/biolreprod/article/85/1/97/2530426 | pmc = 3123383 }}</ref> Junction integrity changes as the cells move to the upper layers of the epidermis.<ref name=":9"/>
=== Mucous === The vagina itself does not contain [[mucous gland]]s.<ref name=":10" /><ref>{{cite journal | vauthors = Nunn KL, Wang YY, Harit D, Humphrys MS, Ma B, Cone R, Ravel J, Lai SK | title = Enhanced Trapping of HIV-1 by Human Cervicovaginal Mucus Is Associated with Lactobacillus crispatus-Dominant Microbiota | journal = mBio | volume = 6 | issue = 5 | pages = e01084-15 | date = October 2015 | pmid = 26443453 | pmc = 4611035 | doi = 10.1128/mBio.01084-15 }}</ref> Though [[Mucus|mucous]] is not produced by the vaginal epithelium, mucous originates from the cervix.<ref name=":11" /> The cervical mucous that is located inside the vagina can be used to assess fertility in ovulating women.<ref name=":10">{{Cite web|url=https://nfp.marquette.edu/nfp_quick_inst_mucus.php|title=NFP Quick Instructions for the Marquette Model (Mucus Only)|last=|first=|date=2018|website=|publisher=Marquette University|access-date=}}</ref> The [[Bartholin's glands]] and [[Skene's gland]]s located at the entrance of the vagina do produce mucous.<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=3s_s6-G3hVwC&pg=PA105&lpg=PA105&dq=%22vaginal+mucus%22&source=bl&ots=HwRyOODJko&sig=VcBNgAYdW88nlyrVH-ldz8tnlkw&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjzk8313qzZAhVDZKwKHTVvBGA4FBDoAQgoMAA#v=onepage&q=%22vaginal%20mucus%22&f=false|title=Sperm Competition in Humans: Classic and Contemporary Readings|last=Shackelford|first=Todd K.|last2=Pound|first2=Nicholas| name-list-format = vanc |date=2006|publisher=Taylor & Francis|isbn=9780387280363}}</ref>
== Development == The epithelium of the vagina originates from three different precursors during embryonic and [[Prenatal development|fetal development]]. These are the vaginal squamous epithelium of the lower vagina, the columnar epithelium of the [[Cervical canal|endocervix]], and the squamous epithelium of the upper vagina. The distinct origins of vaginal epithelium may impact the understanding of [[vaginal anomalies]].<ref name=":2">{{cite journal | vauthors = Reich O, Fritsch H | title = The developmental origin of cervical and vaginal epithelium and their clinical consequences: a systematic review | journal = Journal of Lower Genital Tract Disease | volume = 18 | issue = 4 | pages = 358–60 | date = October 2014 | pmid = 24977630 | doi = 10.1097/lgt.0000000000000023 | url = http://content.wkhealth.com/linkback/openurl?sid=WKPTLP:landingpage&an=00128360-201410000-00016 }}</ref> [[Vaginal adenosis]] is a vaginal anomaly traced to displacement of normal vaginal tissue by other reproductive tissue within the muscular layer and epithelium of the vaginal wall. This displaced tissue often contains glandular tissue and appears as a raised, red surface.<ref name=":6">{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=BbJjfMjDM7cC&pg=PA1388&dq=vagina+epithelium&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwig-PaBk5DZAhUkpFkKHaMIB4MQ6AEIUzAI#v=onepage&q=vagina%20epithelium&f=false|title=The 5-Minute Clinical Consult 2011|last=Domino|first=Frank J.| name-list-format = vanc |date=2010|publisher=Lippincott Williams & Wilkins|isbn=9781608312597}}</ref>
== Cyclic variations == During the luteal and follicular phases of the estrous cycle the structure of the vaginal epithelium varies. The number of cell layers vary during the days of the estrous cycle:
Day 10, 22 layers
Days 12-14, 46 layers
Day 19, 32 layers
Day 24, 24 layers
The glycogen levels in the cells is at its highest immediately before ovulation.<ref name=":8" />
==Lytic cells== [[File:Vagina (mucosa).JPG|thumb|Different layers of the vaginal epithelium]]
Without estrogen, the vaginal epithelium is only a few layers thick. Only small round cells are seen that originate directly from the basal layer ([[Stratum basale|basal cells]]) or the cell layers (parabasal cells) above it. The parabasal cells, which are slightly larger than the basal cells, form a five- to ten-layer cell layer. The parabasal cells can also differentiate into [[histiocyte]]s or glandular cells. Estrogen also influences the changing ratios of nuclear constituents to cytoplasm. As a result of cell aging, cells with shrunken, seemingly foamy cell nuclei (intermediary cells ) develop from the parabasal cells. These can be categorized by means of the nuclear-plasma relation into "upper" and "deep" intermediate cells.<ref name="Knörr" /> Intermediate cells make abundant glycogen and store it. The further nuclear shrinkage and formation of [[mucopolysaccharides]] are distinct characteristics of superficial cells. The mucopolysaccharides form a [[keratin]]-like cell scaffold. Fully keratinized cells without a nucleus are called 'floes'.<ref name="Nauth23">{{cite book | first1 = Hans Friedrich | last1 = Nauth | name-list-format = vanc | title = Gynäkologische Zytodiagnostik|edition = 2nd |publisher = Georg Thieme|location = Stuttgart|year=2014| page = 23 |isbn=978-3-13-131092-7|language=German }}</ref><ref name="Wehrend17">{{cite book | first1 = Axel | last1 = Wehrend | name-list-format = vanc | title=Leitsymptome Gynäkologie und Geburtshilfe beim Hund|publisher=Enke|location = Stuttgart|year = 2010| page = 17|isbn=978-3-8304-1076-8 | language=German }}</ref> Intermediate and superficial cells are constantly exfoliated from the epithelium. The glycogen from these cells is converted to sugars and then fermented by the bacteria of the vaginal flora to lactic acid.<ref name="Nauth23" /><ref name=":7"/> The cells progress through the cell cycle and then decompose (cytolysis) within a week's time. Cytolysis occurs only in the presence of glycogen-containing cells, that is, when the epithelium is degraded to the upper intermediate cells and superficial cells. In this way, the cytoplasm is dissolved, while the cell nuclei remain.<ref name="Nauth23" />
== Epithelial microbiota== [[File:Glycogen structure.svg |thumb|Glycogen is the complex form of sugar present in the vaginal epithelium that is metabolized into lactic acid]]
Low pH is necessary to control vaginal microbiota. Vaginal epithelial cells have a relatively high concentration of glycogen compared to other epithelial cells of the human body. The metabolism of this complex sugar by the lactobacillus dominated microbiome is responsible for vaginal acidity.<ref name=" Aroutcheva ">{{cite journal |author1=Aroutcheva A. |author2=Gariti D. |author3=Simon M. |author4=Shott S. |author5=Faro J. |author6=Simoes J. A. |author7=Gurguis A. |author8=Faro S. | year = 2001 | title = Defense factors of vaginal lactobacilli | url = | journal = Am. J. Obstet. Gynecol. | volume = 185 | issue = | pages = 375–379 }}</ref><ref>Linhares, I. M., P. R. Summers, B. Larsen, P. C. Giraldo, and S. S. Witkin. 2011. Contemporary perspectives on vaginal pH and lactobacilli" ''Am. J. Obstet. Gynecol.'' 204:120.e1-120.e5.</ref><ref>{{cite journal |author1=Redondo-Lopez V. |author2=Cook R. L. |author3=Sobel J. D. | year = 1990 | title = Emerging role of lactobacilli in the control and maintenance of the vaginal bacterial microflora | url = | journal = Rev. Infect. Dis. | volume = 12 | issue = | pages = 856–872 | doi=10.1093/clinids/12.5.856}}</ref>
== Function == The [[Cell junction|cellular junctions]] of the vaginal epithelium help prevent pathogenic microorganisms from entering the body though some are still able to penetrate this barrier. Cells of the cervix and vaginal epithelium generate a [[Mucus|mucous]] barrier (glycocalyx) in which immune cells reside. In addition, [[white blood cell]]s provide additional immunity and are able to infiltrate and move through the vaginal epithelium.<ref name=":1" /> The epithelium is permeable to antibodies, other immune system cells, and [[macromolecule]]s. The permeability of epithelium thus provides access for these immune system components to prevent the passage of invading pathogens into deeper vaginal tissue.<ref name=":9"/> The epithelium further provides a barrier to microbes the synthesis of antimicrobial peptides ([[Beta defensin|beta-defensins]] and [[cathelicidin]]s) and immunoglobulins.<ref name=":1" /> Terminally differentiated, superficial keratinocytes extrude the contents of [[lamellar bodies]] out of the cell to form a specialized, intercellular [[lipid]] envelope that encases the cells of the epidermis and provides a physical barrier to microorganisms.<ref name=":9" />
== Clinical significance== [[File:Chlamydia pneumoniae.jpg|thumb|Vaginal epithelial cells containing chlamydia bacteria]]
=== Disease transmission === Sexually transmitted infections, including HIV are rarely transmitted across intact and healthy epithelium. These protective mechanisms are due to: frequent exfoliation of the superficial cells, low pH, and innate and acquired immunity in the tissue. Research into the protective nature of the vaginal epithelium has been recommended as it would help in the design of [[topical medication]] and microbicides.<ref name=":9"/>
=== Cancer === {{See|Vaginal cancer}} There are very rare malignant growths that can originate in the vaginal epithelium.<ref name=":4">{{Cite web|url=https://www.cancer.gov/types/vaginal/hp/vaginal-treatment-pdq|title=Vaginal Cancer Treatment|last=|first=|date=2017|website=|publisher=National Institutes of Health, National Cancer Institute|language=en|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=February 8, 2018}}</ref> Some are only known through case studies. They are more common in older women.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.cancerresearchuk.org/about-cancer/vaginal-cancer|title=Vaginal cancer {{!}} Vaginal cancer {{!}} Cancer Research UK|last=|first=|date=|website=www.cancerresearchuk.org|language=en|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=February 8, 2018}}</ref>
* [[Vaginal squamous-cell carcinoma]] arises from the [[squamous cell]]s of the epithelium<ref name=":4" /> * [[Vaginal adenocarcinoma]] arises from secretory cells in the epithelium<ref name=":4" /> * [[Clear cell adenocarcinoma of the vagina]] arises in response to prenatal exposure to [[diethylstilbestrol]]<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.cdc.gov/DES/consumers/about/index.html|title=About DES|last=|first=|date=|website=|publisher=Centers for Disease Control and Prevention|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=February 8, 2018}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.cdc.gov/des/consumers/about/effects_daughters.html|title=Known Health Effects for DES Daughters|last=|first=|date=|website=|publisher=Centers for Disease Control and Prevention|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=February 8, 2018}}</ref> * [[Vaginal melanoma]] arises from melanocytes in the epithelium<ref>{{cite journal | vauthors = Kalampokas E, Kalampokas T, Damaskos C | title = Primary Vaginal Melanoma, A Rare and Aggressive Entity. A Case Report and Review of the Literature | journal = In Vivo | volume = 31 | issue = 1 | pages = 133–139 | date = January 2017 | pmid = 28064232 | doi = 10.21873/invivo.11036 | url = http://iv.iiarjournals.org/content/31/1/133 }}</ref>
=== Inflammation === [[File:VaginaHisto.jpg |thumb|Cross section of vaginal epithelium in a post-menopausal woman]] {{See|Vaginitis}}
* [[Candida vaginitis]] is a fungal infection; the discharge is irritating to the vagina and the surrounding skin.<ref name=WH2014>{{cite web|title=Vaginal yeast infections fact sheet|url=http://www.womenshealth.gov/publications/our-publications/fact-sheet/vaginal-yeast-infections.html?from=AtoZ|website=womenshealth.gov|accessdate=5 March 2015|date=December 23, 2014|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150304034823/http://www.womenshealth.gov/publications/our-publications/fact-sheet/vaginal-yeast-infections.html?from=AtoZ|archivedate=4 March 2015|df=}}</ref> * [[Bacterial vaginosis]] ''[[Gardnerella]]'' usually causes a discharge, itching and irritation<ref>{{cite journal | vauthors = Sharma H, Tal R, Clark NA, Segars JH | title = Microbiota and pelvic inflammatory disease | journal = Seminars in Reproductive Medicine | volume = 32 | issue = 1 | pages = 43–9 | date = January 2014 | pmid = 24390920 | pmc = 4148456 | doi = 10.1055/s-0033-1361822 }}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.emedicinehealth.com/bacterial_vaginosis/article_em.htm|title=Bacterial Vaginosis Symptoms, Treatment, Causes & Remedies|work=eMedicineHealth|access-date=2018-02-08}}</ref> * [[Aerobic vaginitis]] thinned reddish vaginal epitherlium, sometimes with erosions or ulcerations and abundant yellowish discharge<ref>{{cite journal | vauthors = Donders G, Bellen G, Rezeberga D | title = Aerobic vaginitis in pregnancy | journal = Bjog | volume = 118 | issue = 10 | pages = 1163–70 | date = September 2011 | pmid = 21668769 | doi = 10.1111/j.1471-0528.2011.03020.x | url = http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1111/j.1471-0528.2011.03020.x/abstract }}</ref>
=== Atrophy === The vaginal epithelium changes significantly when estrogen levels decrease at menopause.<ref>''Vulvovaginal atrophy'' and ''atrophic vaginitis'' have been the preferred terms for this condition and cluster of symptoms until recently. These terms are now regarded as inaccurate in describing changes to the whole genitourinary system occurring after menopause. The term ''atrophic vaginitis'' suggests that the vaginal is inflamed or infected. Though this may be true, inflammation and infection are not the major components of postmenopausal changes to the vagina after menopause. The former terms do not describe the negative effects on the lower urinary tract which can be the most troubling symptoms of menopause for women.</ref> [[Atrophic vaginitis]]<ref>{{cite journal | vauthors = Kim HK, Kang SY, Chung YJ, Kim JH, Kim MR | title = The Recent Review of the Genitourinary Syndrome of Menopause | language = English | journal = Journal of Menopausal Medicine | volume = 21 | issue = 2 | pages = 65–71 | date = August 2015 | pmid = 26357643 | doi = 10.6118/jmm.2015.21.2.65 | url = https://synapse.koreamed.org/DOIx.php?id=10.6118/jmm.2015.21.2.65 }}</ref> usually causes scant odorless discharge with no odor<ref>{{cite journal | vauthors = Faubion SS, Sood R, Kapoor E | title = Genitourinary Syndrome of Menopause: Management Strategies for the Clinician | journal = Mayo Clinic Proceedings | volume = 92 | issue = 12 | pages = 1842–1849 | date = December 2017 | pmid = 29202940 | doi = 10.1016/j.mayocp.2017.08.019 | url = http://linkinghub.elsevier.com/retrieve/pii/S0025619617306390 | via = }}</ref>
== History == The vaginal epithelium has been studied since 1910 by a number of histologists.<ref name=":2" /><!-- This section should be further elaborated, or stepped down for now -->
== Research == The used of nanoprticles that can penetrate the cervical mucous (present in the vagina) and vaginal epithelium has been investigated to determine if medication can be administered in this manner to provide protection from infection of the Herpes simplex virus.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.scientificamerican.com/article/nanomedicine-penetrates-vaginal-mucus/|title=Small Comfort: Nanomedicine Able to Penetrate Bodily Defenses|last=Greenemeier|first=Larry|work=Scientific American|access-date=2018-02-17}}</ref> Nanoparticle drug administration into and through the vaginal epithelium to treat HIV infection is also being investigated.<ref>{{cite journal | vauthors = Saravanan M, Asmalash T, Gebrekidan A, Gebreegziabiher D, Araya T, Hilekiros H, Barabadi H, Ramanathan K | title = Nano-medicine as a newly emerging approach to combat Human Immunodeficiency Virus (HIV) | journal = Pharmaceutical Nanotechnology | volume = 6 | date = February 2018 | pmid = 29424324 | doi = 10.2174/2211738506666180209095710 | url = http://www.eurekaselect.com/159653/article | via = }}</ref>

'''William Zeitlin''' (c. 1850 – 1921, in [[Leipzig]]) was a Russian scholar and bibliographer born at [[Homel]], government (''[[guberniya]]'') of [[Moghilef]], about the middle of the 19th century. He is known especially as the author of ''Kiryat Sefer,'' or ''Bibliotheca Hebraica Post-Mendelssohniana'' (Leipzig, 1891–95), a bibliographical dictionary of modern [[Hebrew literature]] from the beginning of [[Moses Mendelssohn]]'s epoch until 1890. The compilation of this work occupied Zeitlin for twenty years. He made extensive use of [[Benjacob]]'s ''Otzar ha-Sefarim'' and of [[Julius Fürst|Fürst]]'s ''Bibliotheca Judaica'', and visited [[Vilna]] and [[Warsaw]], the centers of the Hebrew book market, as well as many university cities—as [[Königsberg]], [[Berlin]], [[Geneva]], and [[Paris]]—from the libraries of which he gathered additional material for his work.
The ''Qiryat Sefer'' indexes not only works in book form, but also important periodical articles, biographical sketches, and scientific essays, in addition to giving biographical notes on several authors. Zeitlin had previously prepared an index of works written on the [[Hebrew calendar]], in which he enumerates seventy-seven Hebrew works; this index was published by [[Chayyim Jonah Gurland]] in ''Yevreiski Kalendar'' (St. Petersburg, 1882). In the ''Zeit. für Hebr. Bibl.'' (ix.3-4) Zeitlin has published an alphabetical list of anagrams and pseudonyms of modern Hebrew writers; he was also a contributor to several Hebrew periodicals, writing mostly biographical articles.
